result.name: Hospitality, Wellness, and Leisure Services, B.S.

templateAssets.content:
The articulation information in Assist.org not only shows a link to the admission requirements (aka our Major Specific Criteria webpage) but also Cal State LA graduation requirements that may be completed at the lower-division level, prior to transferring to the University. The diversity requirement is a graduation requirement, not an admission requirement. The diversity requirement may be completed prior to, or after, transferring to the University.


For the Cal State LA degree, students will be required to complete two courses (six units) certified as diversity courses, at least one focusing on issues of race and ethnicity and their intersectionality with other social categories that structure inequality in society. These courses can be completed either at the lower-division or upper-division level from among courses satisfying GE requirements.


Please view the General Education/Breadth agreements for the lower-division courses that will meet the Diversity (d) and Race & Ethnicity (re) Requirements.

Major Specific Criteria


This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to the major. Cal State LA lower-division course numbers range from 1000 - 2999. Students are advised to seek advisement from a counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Los Angeles and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Additional admissions criteria for the major can be found on the Major Specific Criteria campus website. Please note that admissions requirements can vary by term so check back to see if there are any changes.

The Bachelor of Science Degree in Hospitality, Wellness, and Leisure Services is organized to provide knowledge and skills in the areas of restaurant and lodging, wellness (nutrition and health), revenue and cost controls, human resources, cultural competencies, and customer expectations.


﻿This degree is designed to provide leadership opportunities for students interested in a career in the Hospitality industry in positions such as hotels and resorts, restaurants and commercial food service, meeting and event planning, tourism destinations and attractions, leisure and recreation, airlines, cruises, and other transportation, environmentally sustainable and cultural tourism development, and spa and wellness management. Students may also prepare for graduate study in Hospitality Management.


﻿Program Learning Outcomes:

﻿

  1. Analyze the impact of emerging trends within nutrition, health, and wellness as it relates to the hospitality and customer experience.
  2. Employ a variety of operational and logistics skills to deliver a high quality hospitality, wellness, and leisure experiences.
  3. Demonstrate essential financial, communication, and human resource skills needed to operate a successful and financially sound hospitality business.
  4. Analyze how cultural differences, traditions, and social inequality shape the hospitality workplace and experience.
  5. Apply management and leadership knowledge and skills to the field of hospitality, wellness, and leisure services.




﻿Additional Requirement for the Major


Students are required to take an upper-division GE block C course (3 units).
